708296f-b.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Mews
708296f-b.text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, north from the Washington Mews (right of No. 1) and across East 8th Street.
The apartment structure, No. 1 Fifth Avenue, occupying the Avenue frontage between the above two points is at the right and only partially appears. Opposite same is the 5-story Hotel Brevoort. This is at the N.E. corner of 8th Street. Above East 9th Street begins the uniform utilitarian apartment dwellings, identified with New York.
February 24, 1933
Views 1, 2
P. L. Sperr

708296f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Mews
708296f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, north from the Washington Mews (right of No. 1) and across East 8th Street.
The apartment structure, No. 1 Fifth Avenue, occupying the Avenue frontage between the above two points is at the right and only partially appears. Opposite same is the 5-story Hotel Brevoort. This is at the N.E. corner of 8th Street. Above East 9th Street begins the uniform utilitarian apartment dwellings, identified with New York.
February 24, 1933
Views 1, 2
P. L. Sperr

723973f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Avenue - Washington Mews
723973f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, from Washington Mews (left) to Washington Square (right), showing the rears of the buildings that face on the Park. These are the holdings of the Sailors' Snug Harbor Corp. and have an interesting background. Originally intended for a home for retired seamen, they are now rented to private individuals. The current lack of response has caused the Corp. to come to the conclusion that modern times demand modern conveniences. Renovations were therefore compulsory in order to protect their equity.
Views 2 and 3 show details of this work. Appearing in the latter, are the 2-story studio's at the rear of the towering apartment building, No. 1 Fifth Avenue. These are former stables and front on the north side of the Mews, extending eastward to University Place.
View 1: March 29, 1933
Views 2, 3: May 10, 1939
P. L. Sperr
